options: virtual seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The reasons why Latin America is so distinctively unequal, including past forces (e.g., colonization) and modern forces (e.g., authoritarian regimes, economic factors, political corruption)

We learned about and discussed political inequality in Latin American countries across different dimensions (wealth, race, gender, subnational). The first few weeks of thee course focused on the origins and drivers of this inequality, while the latter half addressed how modern democracies and autocracies in the region function contemporaneously. Throughout the semester, we looked at a range of analytical and empirical studies, developing a better understanding of how these tools are used in research.
a deep understanding of economic inequality throughout Latin America.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The insight Professor De La O shares of the greatest assets, if not the greatest asset, of the course. She is extremely knowledgeable on every topic we address, routinely offering and citing additional sources of literature to provide a more holistic approach. She further has first-hand experience with most of the topics we address.

Strengths are definitely the material discussed and the presentation format for our seminar assessments. A small weakness I would say was the flow of the class. Sometimes I feel that we went off on tangents and this made it hard to stay engaged during the full two hours.

The topics for each week, as well as the readings, were really interesting. I also appreciated the diversity in the backgrounds of students in the seminar, as we were able to take either our personal experiences or insight from other classes to contribute to seminar conversations. Prof. De La O did a great job of facilitating conversation and posing interesting questions to the group. 

Learning more about the Latin American countries and their histories would have been helpful. While the task force presentations helped with this, I think having more of a preliminary understanding of the region would have led to more insightful conversations about the empirical research.

Overall, this was a really wonderful course!
Great course with super interesting material. I think the course could have maybe had a clearer structure overall, but the readings set the tone for each class very nicely.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It all worked pretty well in spite of covid.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. This course is both engaging and relaxed. I never felt overwhelmed by the workload, but I always felt like I was learning something new and useful about the region.
Yes, I learned a lot about politics in Latin America, and specializing in one country allowed me to dig deeply into the material.
Yes! If you're interested in learning more about the region or in getting more exposure to interdisciplinary empirical research.
Yes, if interested in Latin American economies and societies.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
